author: paulhauner
content: I'm not immediately concerned about the slashings; the same validator running on two VCs won't cause slashable attestations whilst both VCs have the same view of the head. During chain instability is when the VCs will differ and start to produce slashable messages.

author: m.kalinin
content:
There was no finality, and for some reason the proposer in slot 557 decided to propose the atop of alternative terminal block instead of keep building the PoS chain. But 557 was orphaned by the network -- it is a missed slot in the canonical chain which is expected behaviour. The question is why the proposer in that slot decided to do so, do we have more logs

The validator of that slot is run by Teku (https://goerli.beaconcha.in/validator/125303). <@&836981489430036500> can we investigation in why the proposal in 3639557 wasn't made on top of the canonical chain? was the node out of sync?

author: m.kalinin
content: Maybe you have block header in logs, I am curious which beacon block is the parent of this odd 557 block?

author: m.kalinin
content: I guess it's emitted each time the merge transition block is processed by your CL client implementation

content: I would not worry about seeing this message twice

author: intothenetwork
content: Hello, hows it going on the validators and developers side? Any major problems/bugs to take note of?

author: ravensslayer
content: I've noticed a persistent bug across all 3 testnets of old software and/or misconfigured validators

author: ajsutton
content: This was from a teku+besu node where besu had incorrectly told us the canonical chain was invalid. So we had no vaild blocks we could import and eventually reached a slot we were due to propose in. The besu team are looking into it to confirm that's the issue, but certainly the block proposal was on the best block the node had at the time.

author: ajsutton
content: There were likely another couple of blocks published from that node which had long periods of empty slots before them as well based on the metrics I can see.

author: ajsutton
content: It's back following the canonical chain again now btw. Restarted Teku and it reexecuted the block it was previously told was invalid and it imported correctly this time, so likely a race condition that caused it to be marked invalid the first time.

author: funnygiulio
content: By the way, i have a curiosity

author: funnygiulio
content: more in general

author: funnygiulio
content: how did a POA chain generate 2 terminal blocks

author: funnygiulio
content: they are still under "authority", and not as chaotic as PoW

author: m.kalinin
content: My understanding is that when selected signer doesn't propose a block in time other signers make a proposal instead. But the selected ones wins as it has Difficulty=2 while the others are coming with Difficulty=1

author: parithosh
content: ^yup

author: gwintery
content: So is it correct to say that this is unique to the PoA network, and not replicable in PoW?

author: funnygiulio
content: what luck lol

author: m.kalinin
content: In PoW someone may mine a terminal block with Difficulty value greater than of the already mined terminal block and get into the same situation

author: gwintery
content: Then I guess this was a very good luck that we caught this edge case!

author: gwintery
content: Thanks for explaining, wondering if this is exploitable with the f2pool type of attack

author: m.kalinin
content: There is a Hive test that checks two terminal blocks scenario, so, clients can do a fix and check their implementations
